A **giant rat**, r, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [tiny](/wiki/Tiny "Tiny") [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [animal](/wiki/Animal "Animal") that is a slightly stronger and [weightier](/wiki/Weight "Weight") form of [rodent](/wiki/Rodent "Rodent"), and can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").

A giant rat has a single bite attack.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.4 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [5.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [5.6 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [5.7 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated giant rats are always created hostile, and may appear in small [groups](/wiki/Group "Group"). A [sewer rat](/wiki/Sewer_rat "Sewer rat") can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a giant rat.

[Wererats](/wiki/Wererat "Wererat") can summon hostile giant rats by calling for help, with a 2⁄9 chance of generating a hostile giant rat on each adjacent square, and a character that gets [lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy") from a wererat can similarly summon tame giant rats using the [#monster](/wiki/Monster_\(command\) "Monster (command)") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command") with at least 10 [power](/wiki/Power "Power").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

The giant rat is the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster for [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), making up 96⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Healer quest](/wiki/Healer_quest "Healer quest"). They also appear among the random r that are part of the first quest [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for Healers and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

## Strategy

Giant rats are barely stronger than sewer rats and give slightly more nutrition, but are no more significant as threats. As with sewer rats, only the weakest and/or unluckiest starting characters will have any trouble with giant rats.

## History

The giant rat first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, both based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial bestiary for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

From [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d") to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), the giant rat appears if the ROCKMOLE [compile-time option](/wiki/Compile-time_option "Compile-time option") is *not* defined, and is otherwise replaced by the [rock mole](/wiki/Rock_mole "Rock mole"). [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0") includes both the giant rat and rock mole in its default bestiary.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Giant rat](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giant_rat "wikipedia:Giant rat")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Giant Rat of Sumatra](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giant_Rat_of_Sumatra "wikipedia:Giant Rat of Sumatra")***

The name "giant rat" has been applied to various species of large rats, as well as large rat-like animals, and larger versions of ordinarily-small animals are a popular form of creature in science-fiction and fantasy media.

The giant rat appears in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where it is explicitly based on "the giant Sumatran sort" in the first edition *Monster Manual*: the Sumatran rat, or [large bamboo rat](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/large_bamboo_rat "wikipedia:large bamboo rat") (*Rhizomys sumatrensis*), is a species of rodent in the family *Spalacidae* found in east and southeast Asia - it is one of four species of bamboo rat. Large bamboo rats can reach lengths of nearly 50 cm (20 in) with a 20 cm (7.9 in) tail, and may weigh up to 4 kilograms (8.8 lb); their typical diet includes bamboo roots as well as cultivated tapioca and sugarcane, and they are hunted as food by human beings. The "Giant Rat of Sumatra" that appears in [Arthur Conan Doyle](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle "wikipedia:Arthur Conan Doyle") story "[The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Adventure_of_the_Sussex_Vampire "wikipedia:The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire")" and other stories featuring [Sherlock Holmes](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes "wikipedia:Sherlock Holmes") may also be based on the large bamboo rat.

The giant rats of *Dungeons & Dragons* settings, also known as "dire rats", are capable of working exceptionally well in groups and often take advantage of numbers to attack more efficiently. They generally avoid attacking stronger creatures, especially those wielding fire, unless driven by extreme hunger or compelled to do so by a wererat or vampire. Giant rats are also excellent swimmers, and inhabit sewers and other subterranean areas such as crypts, dungeons and even graveyards. Giant rat bites had a small chance of transmitting a serious disease, and victims were recommended to seek immediate clerical attention.

## Variants

In variants that incorporate the [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict") patch, Convicts can pacify or tame giant rats by [chatting](/wiki/Chatting "Chatting") to them. Variants with the Convict role also give the giant rat multiple tiers of growth similar to other starting pets: a sewer rat can grow up into a giant rat, then an [enormous rat](/wiki/Enormous_rat "Enormous rat"), and in all variants except [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") they can become a [rodent of unusual size](/wiki/Rodent_of_unusual_size "Rodent of unusual size").

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), giant rats are not randomly generated in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"). They can be tamed by throwing [cheese](/wiki/Cheese "Cheese") at them, and consider the food a treat.

Twenty giant rats appear on the [rat level](/wiki/Rat_level "Rat level") at level creation: eight are placed in [the Rat King's](/wiki/The_Rat_King_\(SLASH%27EM\) "The Rat King (SLASH'EM)") room, and three each are placed in four other rooms in the level.

Giant rats appear among the random r that are part of the first quest monster class for [Yeomen](/wiki/Yeomen "Yeomen") and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Yeoman quest](/wiki/Yeoman_quest "Yeoman quest").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), giant rats are [omnivores](/wiki/Omnivore "Omnivore") rather than carnivores.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), giant rats are incapable of passing through [iron bars](/wiki/Iron_bars "Iron bars") like in *NetHack* and most other variants.

### SpliceHack

[SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack") uses the same map for the rat level as SLASH'EM, with giant rats generated accordingly.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), giant rats are incapable of passing through iron bars as in xNetHack.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), an alternate "sewer" map is used for the rat level, with five giant rats placed on particular squares in the Rat King's dwelling at level creation. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), the rat level has an equal chance of using either the SLASH'EM room-and-corridors map or the SlashTHEM sewer map, with giant rats generated accordingly. Hack'EM also has the Yeoman role and quest, with SLASH'EM generation details applying.

## Encyclopedia entry

Rats are long-tailed rodents. They are aggressive,  
omnivorous, and adaptable, often carrying diseases.  
   
"The rat," said O'Brien, still addressing his invisible  
audience, "although a rodent, is carnivorous. You are aware  
of that. You will have heard of the things that happen in  
the poor quarters of this town. In some streets a woman dare  
not leave her baby alone in the house, even for five minutes.  
The rats are certain to attack it. Within quite a small time  
they will strip it to the bones. They also attack sick or  
dying people. They show astonishing intelligence in knowing  
when a human being is helpless."

\[ 1984, by George Orwell ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/were.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 144](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/were.c#L144)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Giant rat

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
r giant rat
Difficulty 2
Attacks Bite 1d3
r giant rat
Difficulty 2
Attacks

Bite 1d3

Base level 1
Base experience 8
Speed 10
Base AC 7
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 30
Nutritional value 30
Size Tiny
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

A giant rat:

  • has no hands.
  • is an animal.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can be seen through infravision.
  • normally appears in small groups.
Reference monst.c#line736

A giant rat, r, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is a tiny carnivorous animal that is a slightly stronger and weightier form of rodent, and can be seen via infravision.

A giant rat has a single bite attack.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 dNetHack
    • 5.3 xNetHack
    • 5.4 SpliceHack
    • 5.5 EvilHack
    • 5.6 SlashTHEM
    • 5.7 Hack'EM
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Randomly-generated giant rats are always created hostile, and may appear in small groups. A sewer rat can grow up into a giant rat.

Wererats can summon hostile giant rats by calling for help, with a 2⁄9 chance of generating a hostile giant rat on each adjacent square, and a character that gets lycanthropy from a wererat can similarly summon tame giant rats using the #monster extended command with at least 10 power.[1]

The giant rat is the first quest monster for Healers, making up 96⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Healer quest. They also appear among the random r that are part of the first quest monster class for Healers and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

Strategy

Giant rats are barely stronger than sewer rats and give slightly more nutrition, but are no more significant as threats. As with sewer rats, only the weakest and/or unluckiest starting characters will have any trouble with giant rats.

History

The giant rat first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, both based on Jay Fenlason's Hack, and is included in the initial bestiary for Hack 1.0.

From NetHack 1.3d to NetHack 2.3e, the giant rat appears if the ROCKMOLE compile-time option is not defined, and is otherwise replaced by the rock mole. NetHack 3.0.0 includes both the giant rat and rock mole in its default bestiary.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Giant rat
Wikipedia has an article about:
Giant Rat of Sumatra

The name "giant rat" has been applied to various species of large rats, as well as large rat-like animals, and larger versions of ordinarily-small animals are a popular form of creature in science-fiction and fantasy media.

The giant rat appears in Dungeons & Dragons, where it is explicitly based on "the giant Sumatran sort" in the first edition Monster Manual: the Sumatran rat, or large bamboo rat (Rhizomys sumatrensis), is a species of rodent in the family Spalacidae found in east and southeast Asia - it is one of four species of bamboo rat. Large bamboo rats can reach lengths of nearly 50 cm (20 in) with a 20 cm (7.9 in) tail, and may weigh up to 4 kilograms (8.8 lb); their typical diet includes bamboo roots as well as cultivated tapioca and sugarcane, and they are hunted as food by human beings. The "Giant Rat of Sumatra" that appears in Arthur Conan Doyle story "The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire" and other stories featuring Sherlock Holmes may also be based on the large bamboo rat.

The giant rats of Dungeons & Dragons settings, also known as "dire rats", are capable of working exceptionally well in groups and often take advantage of numbers to attack more efficiently. They generally avoid attacking stronger creatures, especially those wielding fire, unless driven by extreme hunger or compelled to do so by a wererat or vampire. Giant rats are also excellent swimmers, and inhabit sewers and other subterranean areas such as crypts, dungeons and even graveyards. Giant rat bites had a small chance of transmitting a serious disease, and victims were recommended to seek immediate clerical attention.

Variants

In variants that incorporate the Convict patch, Convicts can pacify or tame giant rats by chatting to them. Variants with the Convict role also give the giant rat multiple tiers of growth similar to other starting pets: a sewer rat can grow up into a giant rat, then an enormous rat, and in all variants except UnNetHack they can become a rodent of unusual size.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, giant rats are not randomly generated in Gehennom. They can be tamed by throwing cheese at them, and consider the food a treat.

Twenty giant rats appear on the rat level at level creation: eight are placed in the Rat King's room, and three each are placed in four other rooms in the level.

Giant rats appear among the random r that are part of the first quest monster class for Yeomen and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Yeoman quest.

dNetHack

In dNetHack and notdNetHack, giant rats are omnivores rather than carnivores.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, giant rats are incapable of passing through iron bars like in NetHack and most other variants.

SpliceHack

SpliceHack uses the same map for the rat level as SLASH'EM, with giant rats generated accordingly.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, giant rats are incapable of passing through iron bars as in xNetHack.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, an alternate "sewer" map is used for the rat level, with five giant rats placed on particular squares in the Rat King's dwelling at level creation. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, the rat level has an equal chance of using either the SLASH'EM room-and-corridors map or the SlashTHEM sewer map, with giant rats generated accordingly. Hack'EM also has the Yeoman role and quest, with SLASH'EM generation details applying.

Encyclopedia entry

Rats are long-tailed rodents. They are aggressive,
omnivorous, and adaptable, often carrying diseases.
 
"The rat," said O'Brien, still addressing his invisible
audience, "although a rodent, is carnivorous. You are aware
of that. You will have heard of the things that happen in
the poor quarters of this town. In some streets a woman dare
not leave her baby alone in the house, even for five minutes.
The rats are certain to attack it. Within quite a small time
they will strip it to the bones. They also attack sick or
dying people. They show astonishing intelligence in knowing
when a human being is helpless."

[ 1984, by George Orwell ]

References

  1. ↑ src/were.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 144

A '''giant rat''', {{monsym|giant rat}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a [[tiny]] [[carnivorous]] [[animal]] that is a slightly stronger and [[weight]]ier form of [[rodent]], and can be seen via [[infravision]].

A giant rat has a single bite attack.

==Generation==
Randomly-generated giant rats are always created hostile, and may appear in small [[group]]s. A [[sewer rat]] can [[grow up]] into a giant rat.

[[Wererat]]s can summon hostile giant rats by calling for help, with a {{frac|2|9}} chance of generating a hostile giant rat on each adjacent square, and a character that gets [[lycanthropy]] from a wererat can similarly summon tame giant rats using the [[Monster (command)|#monster]] [[extended command]] with at least 10 [[power]].{{refsrc|src/were.c|144|nethack=3.6.7}}

The giant rat is the first [[quest]] monster for [[Healer]]s, making up {{frac|96|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Healer quest]]. They also appear among the random {{white|r}} that are part of the first quest [[monster class]] for Healers and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated there.

==Strategy==
Giant rats are barely stronger than sewer rats and give slightly more nutrition, but are no more significant as threats. As with sewer rats, only the weakest and/or unluckiest starting characters will have any trouble with giant rats.

==History==
The giant rat first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, both based on [[Jay Fenlason's Hack]], and is included in the initial bestiary for [[Hack 1.0]].

From [[NetHack 1.3d]] to [[NetHack 2.3e]], the giant rat appears if the ROCKMOLE [[compile-time option]] is ''not'' defined, and is otherwise replaced by the [[rock mole]]. [[NetHack 3.0.0]] includes both the giant rat and rock mole in its default bestiary.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Giant rat}}
{{wikipedia|Giant Rat of Sumatra}}
The name "giant rat" has been applied to various species of large rats, as well as large rat-like animals, and larger versions of ordinarily-small animals are a popular form of creature in science-fiction and fantasy media.

The giant rat appears in ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', where it is explicitly based on "the giant Sumatran sort" in the first edition ''Monster Manual'': the Sumatran rat, or [[Wikipedia:large bamboo rat|large bamboo rat]] (''Rhizomys sumatrensis''), is a species of rodent in the family ''Spalacidae'' found in east and southeast Asia - it is one of four species of bamboo rat. Large bamboo rats can reach lengths of nearly 50 cm (20 in) with a 20 cm (7.9 in) tail, and may weigh up to 4 kilograms (8.8 lb); their typical diet includes bamboo roots as well as cultivated tapioca and sugarcane, and they are hunted as food by human beings. The "Giant Rat of Sumatra" that appears in [[wikipedia:Arthur Conan Doyle|Arthur Conan Doyle]] story "[[wikipedia:The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire|The Adventure of the Sussex Vampire]]" and other stories featuring [[wikipedia:Sherlock Holmes|Sherlock Holmes]] may also be based on the large bamboo rat.

The giant rats of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' settings, also known as "dire rats", are capable of working exceptionally well in groups and often take advantage of numbers to attack more efficiently. They generally avoid attacking stronger creatures, especially those wielding fire, unless driven by extreme hunger or compelled to do so by a wererat or vampire. Giant rats are also excellent swimmers, and inhabit sewers and other subterranean areas such as crypts, dungeons and even graveyards. Giant rat bites had a small chance of transmitting a serious disease, and victims were recommended to seek immediate clerical attention.

==Variants==
In variants that incorporate the [[Convict]] patch, Convicts can pacify or tame giant rats by [[chatting]] to them. Variants with the Convict role also give the giant rat multiple tiers of growth similar to other starting pets: a sewer rat can grow up into a giant rat, then an [[enormous rat]], and in all variants except [[UnNetHack]] they can become a [[rodent of unusual size]].

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], giant rats are not randomly generated in [[Gehennom]]. They can be tamed by throwing [[cheese]] at them, and consider the food a treat.

Twenty giant rats appear on the [[rat level]] at level creation: eight are placed in [[The Rat King (SLASH'EM)|the Rat King's]] room, and three each are placed in four other rooms in the level.

Giant rats appear among the random {{white|r}} that are part of the first quest monster class for [[Yeomen]] and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Yeoman quest]].

In [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]], giant rats are [[omnivore]]s rather than carnivores.

[[SpliceHack]] uses the same map for the rat level as SLASH'EM, with giant rats generated accordingly.

In [[SlashTHEM]], an alternate "sewer" map is used for the rat level, with five giant rats placed on particular squares in the Rat King's dwelling at level creation. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

In [[Hack'EM]], the rat level has an equal chance of using either the SLASH'EM room-and-corridors map or the SlashTHEM sewer map, with giant rats generated accordingly. Hack'EM also has the Yeoman role and quest, with SLASH'EM generation details applying.

Rats are long-tailed rodents.  They are aggressive,
omnivorous, and adaptable, often carrying diseases.
 
"The rat," said O'Brien, still addressing his invisible

==References==
<references/>

[[Category:Monsters]]
